column2:
Q0.1 What is your primary role in the AECO (Architecture, Engineering, Construction, and Operation) domain? (Please select one)
If multiple roles apply, please select the one that best represents your current or most frequent involvement.
column3:
Q0.2  Please indicate your total years of professional experience in the AECO domain. (Please select one)
This helps us understand how your perspective relates to design practice and project involvement.
column4:
Q0.3  How familiar are you with BIM and BIM-related parametric design workflows? 
For example (but not limited to):
Using tools such as Revit, Archicad, Rhino/Grasshopper, SketchUp, AutoCAD, Dynamo, Tekla Structures, SOFiSTiK, SAP2000, ETABS, Robot Structural Analysis, RFEM, Bentley STAAD.Pro, Bentley OpenBuildings, Allplan, Navisworks, or Civil 3D—especially for tasks involving parametric modeling, design coordination, or modular layouts—would be considered as familiarity with BIM-based design workflows.
column5:
Q0.4 In which country are you primarily based for your professional work?

This helps us understand the geographic context of your experience in AECO practices. You may skip this question if you prefer not to share this information.
column6:
Q1.1.1 Case 1 - Selection
Select the option you would most likely implement in practice.

The upper part shows a 3D view of the building and the selected floor.
The lower part presents a floor plan view, highlighting the main components—structural and non-structural walls, and structural columns—along with the proposed structural grids (in red) and non-structural grids (in blue).

If all 3 options were found to require major changes, please specify the issues under the “Other” response.
column7: Q1.1.2  What were the reasons for your preference? (Please select all that apply)
column8:
Q1.1.3 Case 1 - Improvement
Would you use the provided grid configuration as-is, and if not, what changes would you make based on it?
column9:
Q1.1.4 Case 1 - Improvement
Would you use the provided grid configuration as-is, and if not, what changes would you make based on it?
column10:
Q1.1.5 For a design model shown in this case, approximately how much time would you spend creating a grid system from scratch for the whole building (assuming no pre-existing grids, no information about the original design intent, and no prior knowledge of the project)?
This may include tasks such as:
- Reviewing the 3D model
- Analyzing the global and local building layout
- Identifying structural and non-structural elements
- Placing grids across all floors
- Defining alignment relationships
- Setting distance parameters or modular spacing rules
Please estimate the time in minutes (You may also leave a short explanation if your estimate depends on specific assumptions or project factors in the 'Other' block):

column46: Q2.1 In your experience, how important are reference grids in supporting the design modeling and coordination processes? (Please rate it on a scale from 1 to 5)
column47: Q2.2 Did any of the grid options present practical issues or layout conflicts? (Please select all that apply)
column48:
Q2.3 We acknowledge that expert review is generally necessary when using the grid options. To what extent do you believe expert intervention is required on average across all eight design cases? 
(Please rate on a scale from 1 to 5)
1 – The grid options are highly suitable and can be used directly without any modifications.
2 – The grid options are generally suitable and require only minor adjustments by designers.
3 – The grid options need moderate modifications to meet practical requirements.
4 – The results require extensive expert revisions and adjustments.
5 – The results are not suitable for practical use without a complete redesign or intervention.
column49:
Q2.4 We acknowledge that expert review is generally necessary when using the grid options. To what extent do you believe expert intervention is required on average across Manhattan-type design cases (with mostly orthogonal and regular layouts)? 
(Please rate on a scale from 1 to 5)
1 – The grid options are highly suitable and can be used directly without any modifications.
2 – The grid options are generally suitable and require only minor adjustments by designers.
3 – The grid options need moderate modifications to meet practical requirements.
4 – The results require extensive expert revisions and adjustments.
5 – The results are not suitable for practical use without a complete redesign or intervention.
The following are the options previously presented when asking whether the grids could be used directly or would require design modifications.
column50:
Q2.5 We acknowledge that expert review is generally necessary when using the grid options. To what extent do you believe expert intervention is required on average across more complex or irregular design cases (e.g., with non-orthogonal geometry, varying orientations, or unconventional layouts)  ? 
(Please rate on a scale from 1 to 5)
1 – The grid options are highly suitable and can be used directly without any modifications.
2 – The grid options are generally suitable and require only minor adjustments by designers.
3 – The grid options need moderate modifications to meet practical requirements.
4 – The results require extensive expert revisions and adjustments.
5 – The results are not suitable for practical use without a complete redesign or intervention.
The following are the options previously presented when asking whether the grids could be used directly or would require design modifications.
column51:
Q2.6 What aspects of automated grid generation do you find most useful or promising in your design workflow?
Feel free to mention specific tasks, benefits, or situations where it added value.
column52:
Q2.7 Do you have any suggestions or ideas for improving automated grid generation tools or their integration into design practice?
We welcome feedback related to usability, logic, visualization, or collaboration.

column51: I believe it is very useful in all cases to see suggested grid lines, as it saves time. For Manhattan-type projects, the grids mostly fit well since the model is not complicated. Designers can check and easily update them with minor changes if necessary. However, in more complex projects, trying to understand the grids might also take time and cause confusion. Still, I believe it generally saves time compared to creating them from scratch.
column52: When the tool creates them, it would be helpful to easily adjust their positions directly from the suggested version, as well as remove some of them or add new ones if needed.

column51: the process of grid generation takes a minimum amount of time for the steps mentioned, its very important to get this automation but with minimum complexity. The time taken by the original desginer and the time taken by a user and the time taken by a designer wo takes up the renewal or renovation will be different and therefore the less the complexity the less time it takes to work with the model.
column52: the idea is good generally but i would reccomend to reduce the complexity of grids and use minimal functions considering that its automatically generated , more lines can be added if needed but deleting excessive grids is in my opinion not neeeded.

column51: Grid automation may be affected by large-scale projects (like the Mall of Saudi Arabia, for example, 261,000 square meters); otherwise, as mentioned, it's not relatively important for small-scale projects. However, I would say that grid determination is relative to the designer's experience, so the same design might have 200 grids or 202 grids, and both are right. What is most important is that the grids cover the requirements, such as assigning column locations to the grid, so the distance between columns and the grid should not extend more than a specific value, so it would be easier later to handle the model.
column52: I would recommend using AI to gather the data from already done projects to get a suitable pattern of aligning the grids with elements, not a specific algorithm to code.
